t: Proverbs 23
When*pn you sit down to eat with a ruler, Consider*ld carefully what is*i before you;
And*ld put a knife to your throat If*ld you are*i a man given to appetite.
Do*ld not desire his delicacies, For*ld they are*i deceptive food.
Do*ln not overwork to be rich; Because*ld of your own understanding, cease!
Will*ld you set your eyes on that which is not? For*ld riches*i certainly make themselves wings; They*ld fly away like an eagle toward*i heaven.
Do*ln not eat the bread of a miser, Nor*ld desire his delicacies;
For*ld as he thinks in his heart, so is*i he. “Eat*ld and drink!” he says to you, But*ld his heart is not with you.
The*ld morsel you have eaten, you will vomit up, And*ld waste your pleasant words.
Do*ln not speak in the hearing of a fool, For*ld he will despise the wisdom of your words.
Do*ln not remove the ancient landmark, Nor*ld enter the fields of the fatherless;
For*ld their Redeemer is*i mighty; He*ld will plead their cause against you.
Apply*ln your heart to instruction, And*ld your ears to words of knowledge.
Do*ln not withhold correction from a child, For*ld if*i you beat him with a rod, he will not die.
You*ld shall beat him with a rod, And*ld deliver his soul from hell.
My*ln son, if your heart is wise, My*ld heart will rejoice—indeed, I myself;
Yes,*ld my inmost being will rejoice When*ld your lips speak right things.
Do*ln not let your heart envy sinners, But*ld be*i zealous*i for the fear of the Lord*s all the day;
For*ld surely there is a hereafter, And*ld your hope will not be cut off.
Hear,*ln my son, and be wise; And*ld guide your heart in the way.
Do*ld not mix with winebibbers, Or*ild with gluttonous eaters of meat;
For*ld the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty, And*ld drowsiness will clothe a*i man*i with rags.
Listen*ln to your father who begot you, And*ld do not despise your mother when she is old.
Buy*ln the truth, and do not sell it,*i Also*ild wisdom and instruction and understanding.
The*ld father of the righteous will greatly rejoice, And*ld he who begets a wise child*i will delight in him.
Let*ld your father and your mother be glad, And*ld let her who bore you rejoice.
My*ln son, give me your heart, And*ld let your eyes observe my ways.
For*ld a harlot is*i a deep pit, And*ld a seductress is*i a narrow well.
She*ld also lies in wait as for*i a victim, And*ld increases the unfaithful among men.
Who*ln has woe? Who*ld has sorrow? Who*ld has contentions? Who*ld has complaints? Who*ld has wounds without cause? Who*ld has redness of eyes?
Those*ld who linger long at the wine, Those*ld who go in search of mixed wine.
Do*ld not look on the wine when it is red, When*ld it sparkles in the cup, When*ild it swirls around smoothly;
At*ld the last it bites like a serpent, And*ld stings like a viper.
Your*ld eyes will see strange things, And*ld your heart will utter perverse things.
Yes,*ld you will be like one who lies down in the midst of the sea, Or*ld like one who lies at the top of the mast, saying:*i
“They*ld have struck me, but*i I was not hurt; They*ld have beaten me, but I did not feel it.*i When*ld shall I awake, that I may seek another drink?”*i
